slides.headline: The Problem
bullets: Most people study, but don’t learn.
Re-reading feels productive; it doesn’t stick.
Real learning needs retrieval and application.
slides.note: If studying feels easy, it’s probably not working.

slides.headline: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: pull info from memory.
Deliberate practice: target your weak spots.
slides.note: These three separate ‘I saw it’ from ‘I can do it.’

slides.headline: Active Recall: What to Do
bullets: Blurting: write all you remember, then check gaps.
Practice questions: exam-style problems, not summaries.
Teach-back: explain it as if tutoring.
Quick example: Answer 10, mark, fix errors.

left.title: Spacing
bullets: Shorter sessions across days beat cramming.

right.title: Interleaving
bullets: Mix topics; avoid marathon single-topic blocks.
Feels harder; that’s why it works.

slides.headline: The Feedback Loop
bullets: After each session, ask three questions.
What did I miss, and why?

slides.headline: A Simple 45-Min Template
slides.note: No fancy motivation needed—just a system.

slides.headline: Technique beats time.
slides.subheadline: Swap re-reading for retrieval, then space it out.
